title: The heartbreaking reason Emma Thompson won't be in the Love Actually sequel
text:

As soon as fans heard Love Actually was getting a sequel there was an outpouring of sheer joy, elation and delight, swiftly followed by hundreds of questions. 
It’s been more than a decade since the rom-com first hit the big screens, so fans were thrilled when it was announced the cast are reuniting for a special Comic Relief movie dubbed Red Nose Day Actually. 
The main question on everyone's lips, though, was will all our favourite characters return? 
“We’re not doing everyone. We’re doing about two-thirds of people," director Richard Curtis said when quizzed about the new film. Liam Neeson, Olivia Olsen and Thomas Brodie-Sangster film Red Nose Day Actually (Photo: WENN.com) 
The two-thirds includes original stars Liam Neeson, Thomas Brodie-Sangster and Hugh Grant. 
But with Alan Rickman's death last year it was unclear whether Emma Thompson would be among the actors reprising their role. 
Now we know, sadly, she won't be back and it's not because the whole thing has been pulled together quickly for Comic Relief. Emma Thompson won't be returning for the Love Actually sequel Read More 37 Love Actually film secrets you probably didn't know 
"Em isn't in it. She just can't do it," director Richard Curtis said. 
Love Actually fanatics have been pondering why the star isn't coming back. It's not because of her Beauty and the Beast press obligations (it's out in a month guys), no, it's for a much sadder reason - she can't face it without Alan Rickman. 
Emma and Alan Rickman were very close, and the actress can't face filming without him. 
Just in case you'd forgotten, or haven't watched the movie a trillion times like everyone else, Rickman played Harry, Karen's husband. He ended up having an affair with his secretary Mia, breaking all our hearts, but mainly Karen's. Alan Rickman and Emma Thompson in Love Actually 
The pair reunited in the airport and it looked like she decided to stay with him for the sake of their two young children. 
If you were wondering if there will be a tribute to Rickman too, there won't be one. “You know, dealing with Alan is very complicated,” Richard Curtis told the Press Association. 
Let's hope there's some sort of reference to Rickman, even just to let us know poor Karen is happy with Harry. 
If not, we'll just pretend they worked through all their issues and lived happily ever after. 
You can watch the 10-minute sequel on March 24 when it airs during the BBC's Red Nose Day. Like us on Facebook
